none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from W. L. Bringhurst, July 8, 1886
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from W. L. Bringhurst, July 8, 1886
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 22 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
[Header]

College Sta. Tex. July 8. 86

My dear Professor:
It gives me pleasure to acknowledge
your piece of a letter. We are all well here. Not
much news. Catalogues just out. We sent you
3 yesterday. The Convention at Austin was a
grand success - About 300 of teachers present
were women & not a good-looking one among
them. When a woman is too ugly or strong-minded
to marry she goes to schoolteaching. You ought
to have seen me playing the agreeable to the
younger sisters.

Are you going to apply for chair of
Math, at Oxford? Put me down for the
Greek, or Latin, or Eng. professorship. I'll
come for $3000 and a house - "Satisfac-
tion guaranteed" - By the way, Wooldridge
and I have bridged the bloody chasm -
and I am negotiating for a building-
site near his university -

I saw Col. Cole at the Convention.
He says he is doing splendid[illegible]t Abilene

**[Header]**

College Sta. Tex. July 8. 86

My dear Professor:
It gives me pleasure to acknowledge
your piece of a letter. We are all well here. Not
much news. Catalogues just out. We sent you
3 yesterday. The Convention at Austin was a
grand success - About 300 of teachers present
were women & not a good-looking one among
them. When a woman is too ugly or strong-minded
to marry she goes to schoolteaching. You ought
to have seen me playing the agreeable to the
younger sisters.

Are you going to apply for chair of
Math, at Oxford? Put me down for the
Greek, or Latin, or Eng. professorship. I'll
come for $3000 and a house - "Satisfac-
tion guaranteed" - By the way, Wooldridge
and I have bridged the bloody chasm -
and I am negotiating for a building-
site near his university -

I saw Col. Cole at the Convention.
He says he is doing splendid[ly at] Abilene

saving money, and got another
baby - He evidently doesn't believe
in the doctrine of limiting population.
The theory is easier than the practice -
        Drop me another line & let
me know something about the Oxford
rumpus -
        Please present my regards, & Mrs
B's to your wife -

                            The thermometer
in this country has been up to 110 in the
shade - You can see the effects on this
ink -

                        Faithfully Yours
                        W. L. Bringhurst.

**Transcribing a Handwritten Letter** Okay, so I have a handwritten document here, a letter on lined paper. The script is cursive, typical of the late 19th or early 20th century. The ink has a brownish tint, which I should note. Overall, the handwriting is quite legible, although I will need to take extra care with some words. I'll proceed line by line. First line reads "saving money, and got another baby - He evidently doesn't believe in the doctrine of limiting population. The theory is easier than the practice -" Then "Drop me another line & let me know something about the Oxford rumpus -" Next is "Please present my regards, & Mrs B's to your wife -". The next section reads, "The thermometer in this country has been up to 110 in the shade - You can see the effects on this ink -". The closing is "Faithfully Yours". Then, the signature looks to be "W. L. Bringhurst." I need to transcribe this into HTML, using `

` for paragraphs and `
` for line breaks where appropriate to keep the same visual layout. I need to make sure to pay attention to where the indents are. I'll need to double check the capitalization and punctuation. I also need to be certain about the signature. The ampersand looks like a plus sign or cross. Let's begin.

saving money, and got another
baby - He evidently doesn't believe
in the doctrine of limiting population.
The theory is easier than the practice -

Drop me another line & let
me know something about the Oxford
rumpus -

Please present my regards, & Mrs
B's to your wife -

The thermometer
in this country has been up to 110 in the
shade - You can see the effects on this
ink -

Faithfully Yours
W. L. Bringhurst.

Okay, I've used the approved HTML tags. Now, I should double check some words to make sure the transcription is correct. "evidently" - yes. "doctrine" - yes. "limiting" - yes. "rumpus" - yes. "Mrs B's" - yes. It looks like the signature 'B' on the signature. "thermometer" - yes. "Bringhurst" - yes, the handwriting is clear, and the signature matches. The indentation in the original document looks like the start of new paragraphs. Okay, I think this is it. Ready to go.
